{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Bill Hader | image = Bill Hader, 2013 San Diego Comic Con-cropped-2.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Hader at the 2013 [[San Diego Comic-Con]] | birth_name = William Thomas Hader Jr. | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1978|6|7}} | birth_place = [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]], [[United States|U.S.]] | active = 1998–present | medium = [[Television]], [[film]] | genre = [[Improvisational theatre|Improvisational comedy]], [[character comedy]], [[sketch comedy]], [[insult comedy]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Maggie Carey]]
|2006|2018|reason=div.}} | children = 3 }} '''William Thomas Hader Jr.''' (born June 7, 1978){{cite web| url=http://www.hollywood.com/celebrities/bill-hader-57635941/| work= [[Hollywood.com]] | title=Bill Hader {{!}} Biography and Filmography {{!}} 1978| accessdate= May 5, 2017}} is an American comedian, actor, producer and writer. He is known for his work on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' (2005–2013), for which he has received three [[Emmy Award|Emmy]] nominations, ''[[South Park]]'' (2009–present), and his [[parody]] series ''[[Documentary Now!]]'' (2015–present). He created and stars in the [[HBO]] series ''[[Barry (TV series)|Barry]]'', which began airing in March 2018 and earned Hader four Emmy nominations for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Comedy Series|Outstanding Comedy Series]], [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series|Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series]], [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Directing for a Comedy Series|Outstanding Directing for a Comedy Series]], and [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Writing for a Comedy Series|Outstanding Writing for a Comedy Series]] in its first season.https://deadline.com/2018/07/2018-emmy-nominations-list-all-nominees-1202425072/ He is also known for his supporting work in comedy films, such as ''[[You, Me and Dupree]]'' (2006), ''[[Hot Rod (film)|Hot Rod]]'' (2007), ''[[Superbad (film)|Superbad]]'' (2007), ''[[Forgetting Sarah Marshall]]'' (2008), ''[[Tropic Thunder]]'' (2008), ''[[Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian]]'' (2009), ''[[Paul (film)|Paul]]'' (2011), ''[[Men in Black 3]]'' (2012), and ''[[Maggie's Plan]]'' (2015). He has also had lead voice roles in ''[[Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs (film)|Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs]]'' (2009), ''[[Inside Out (2015 film)|Inside Out]]'' (2015), and ''[[The Angry Birds Movie]]'' (2016) as well as lead roles in the [[dramedy]] ''[[The Skeleton Twins]]'' (2014) and the romantic comedy ''[[Trainwreck (film)|Trainwreck]]'' (2015). He has also voiced supporting characters in Pixar films, including ''[[Monsters University]]'' and ''[[Finding Dory]]''. ==Early life== Hader was born and raised in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]], the son of Sherri Renee (née Patton) and William Thomas Hader.''[[Finding Your Roots]]'', January 26, 2016, PBS{{Cite news|last=Smith|first=Michael |title=Hader about to be a proud papa|pages=|publisher=Tulsa World|date=September 18, 2009|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/site/printerfriendlystory.aspx?articleid=20090918_283_D1_BillHa114485|accessdate=November 15, 2010}} His father owned an air-freight company and worked as a restaurant manager, truck driver and occasional [[stand-up comedian]];{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/23/movies/23itzk.html?_r=0 |title=A 'Superbad' Geek's Progress |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=September 23, 2007 |first=Dave |last=Itzkoff |accessdate=October 14, 2014 }} his mother was a dance teacher.{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/features/bill-hader-trades-stefon-for-serious-drama-in-the-skeleton-twins-20140911 |title=Bill Hader Trades Stefon for Serious Drama in 'The Skeleton Twins' |publisher=''Rolling Stone'' |date=September 11, 2014 |first=Jonah |last=Weiner |accessdate=October 13, 2014 }} He has two younger sisters, Katie and Kara. His ancestry includes German, Danish, Irish, and English; his surname originates in Germany.{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/weta/finding-your-roots/blog/bill-haders-interactive-family-tree/ |title=Bill Hader's Interactive Family Tree | Finding Your Roots |publisher=PBS |date=2016-01-28 |accessdate=2016-12-21}} Hader attended Patrick Henry Elementary School, [[Edison Preparatory School|Edison Junior High]], and [[Cascia Hall Preparatory School]].Michael Smith, [http://www.tulsaworld.com/entertainment/spot/article.aspx?articleID=070817_8_ES14_Itwas70410 "Super Glad: Native Tulsan Bill Hader moves from ‘SNL’ success to big-budget film roles,"] ''[[Tulsa World]]'', August 17, 2007.Michael Smith, [http://www.tulsaworld.com/spot/article.aspx?subjectid=243&articleid=20090403_282_D1_JasonP931046 "Talking about Tulsa days: Bill Hader finally found a vocation in comedy"], ''[[Tulsa World]]'', April 3, 2009. He had "a hard time focusing on class" and was always "joking around". Though he was not hated by classmates, he felt he never truly fit in and filled his time watching movies and reading. He appreciated [[Monty Python]], [[British comedy]], and the films of [[Mel Brooks]] and [[Woody Allen]], many of which he was introduced to through his father. He made short films with friends and starred in a school production of ''[[The Glass Menagerie]]''. He was unable to gain admission to top [[film school]]s because of his "abysmal" grades, so he instead enrolled at [[The Art Institute of Phoenix]],Gene Triplett, [http://newsok.com/article/3105814 "Funny things about Bill Hader: Growing up in Tulsa as ‘movie nerd' gave comic actor material,"] ''[[The Oklahoman]]'', August 17, 2007. and later [[Scottsdale Community College]]. He worked as an usher at a movie theater in nearby [[Tempe, Arizona|Tempe]], which allowed him to see films for free. He was fired for [[Spoiler (media)|spoiling]] the ending of the 1997 film ''[[Titanic (1997 film)|Titanic]]'' to noisy patrons.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/07/13/bill-hader-mike-sacks-interview-poking-a-dead-frog-_n_5582142.html |title=Bill Hader Got Fired For Spoiling The End Of 'Titanic' & 10 More Facts You Didn't Know |publisher=''The Huffington Post'' |date=July 14, 2014 |first=Katla |last=McGlynn |accessdate=October 14, 2014 }} At Scottsdale, he met Nicholas Jasenovec, the director of ''[[Paper Heart]]''.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/watch-extensive-2-1-2-hour-talk-with-bill-hader-about-his-career-films-and-more-20140813 |title=Watch: Extensive 2 1/2 Hour Talk With Bill Hader About His Career, Films And More |publisher=''Indie Wire'' |date=August 13, 2014 |first=Tess |last=Hoffman |accessdate=October 14, 2014 }} ==Career== ===Early career=== Hader's aspirations of becoming a filmmaker eventually led him to drop out of college and move to Los Angeles in 1999.{{cite news|title=20Q: Bill Hader|work=[[Playboy]]|author=Rob Tannenbaum|date=September 2013|url=http://playboy.co.za/20q-bill-hader|accessdate=November 26, 2015}} His parents were supportive of his decision to move, and Hader used the money they had originally saved for his college education to cover his living expenses when he arrived in Los Angeles. He found work as a [[production assistant]] (PA) while scouring the back pages of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', and he hoped to advance far enough to become an assistant director. He spent much of his young adulthood "lonely and underemployed," filling large amounts of spare time with movie marathons.{{cite news|title=Bill Hader’s Day Off|author=Amos Barhsad|publisher=[[Grantland.com]]|date=August 25, 2014|url=http://grantland.com/features/bill-hader-saturday-night-live-snl-week/|accessdate=November 26, 2015}} He regularly worked 18-hour days as a PA, having little time to pursue his creative ambitions. He worked as a PA on the DVD ''[[Empire of Dreams: The Story of the Star Wars Trilogy]]''; the feature films ''[[James Dean (film)|James Dean]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.esquire.com/features/james-franco/james-franco-bill-hader-0910 |title=Four Introductions to James Franco |publisher=''Esquire'' |date= |first=Bill |last=Hader |accessdate=October 14, 2014 }} ''[[Spider-Man (2002 film)|Spider-Man]]'', and ''[[Collateral Damage (film)|Collateral Damage]]''; as well as a post-production assistant on [[VH1]] television's ''[[The Surreal Life]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.aoltv.com/2010/09/24/snl-star-bill-hader-talks-the-new-season-jon-hamms-return-an/ |title='SNL' Star Bill Hader Talks the New Season, Jon Hamm's Return and His 'Surreal Life' Experience with Corey Feldman |publisher=''The Huffington Post'' |date=September 24, 2010 |first=Kim |last=Potts |accessdate=October 14, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120921063946/http://www.aoltv.com/2010/09/24/snl-star-bill-hader-talks-the-new-season-jon-hamms-return-an/ |archivedate=September 21, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} Hader briefly worked as a PA and stage manager on [[Playboy TV]]'s ''[[Night Calls]]'';{{cite web|url=http://www.ifc.com/fix/2014/09/bill-hader-playboy-tv-kimmel |title=BILL HADER TALKS ABOUT HIS PLAYBOY TV PAST ON KIMMEL |publisher=IFC |date=September 10, 2014 |accessdate=October 14, 2014 }}{{cite web|url=http://uproxx.com/tv/2014/09/bill-hader-jimmy-kimmel-playboy-call-in-show/ |title=Here's Bill Hader Describing What It Was Like To Work The Phones for a Playboy Call-In Sex Show |publisher=Uproxx |date=September 10, 2014 |first=Kris |last=Maske |accessdate=October 14, 2014 }}{{cite web|url=http://observer.com/2014/09/funnyman-bill-hader-on-going-serious-you-have-to-empty-yourself-a-little-bit/ |title=Funnyman Bill Hader on Going Serious: ‘You Have to Empty Yourself a Little Bit’ |publisher=''New York Observer'' |date=September 11, 2014 |first=Vinnie |last=Mancuso |accessdate=October 22, 2014 }} he quit, as he feared it would disappoint his parents.{{cite web|title=5 Jobs You Probably Didn't Know Bill Hader Once Had|author=Brian Steele|date=August 24, 2015|accessdate=November 26, 2015|publisher=[[IFC (TV channel)|IFC.com]]}} He quit being a PA altogether after a bad experience shooting ''[[The Scorpion King]]''. He subsequently secured a job working as a nighttime assistant editor at post-production facility [[Triage Entertainment]]. He invested money into his own short film, but was too embarrassed to release it. Shortly thereafter, Hader and his then-longtime girlfriend broke up.{{cite news|title=How Bill Hader Went from Production Assistant to ''SNL'' Hero to Leading Man|author=Joe Berkowitz|date=September 24, 2014|work=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]|url=http://www.fastcocreate.com/3036180/then-and-now/how-bill-hader-went-from-production-assistant-to-snl-hero-to-leading-man|accessdate=November 26, 2015}} Desperate for a change, he began attending comedy classes with friends at [[improvisational comedy]] enterprise [[the Second City]] in March 2003. He quickly realized that comedy was the creative outlet that he had needed since he made the decision to leave higher education behind, and soon Hader, his new compatriot in comedy Matt Offerman, and their two friends and fellow humor enthusiasts Eric Filipkowski and Mel Cowan, elected to form their own sketch comedy group.{{Cite news|url=https://hollywoodphony.wordpress.com/2008/05/11/my-father-jocko-filipkowski/|title=My father, Jocko Filipkowski|date=2008-05-11|work=hollywoodphony|access-date=2018-04-01|language=en-US}} Christening their group ''Animals from the Future'', the four frequently appeared to small audiences at backyard shows in Van Nuys. Matt's brother, actor [[Nick Offerman]], told his wife, [[Megan Mullally]], about the group.{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2012/08/22/159766489/bill-hader-on-sketch-comedy-his-love-of-old-films |title=Bill Hader on Sketch Comedy, His Love of Old Films |publisher=NPR |date=August 22, 2012 |accessdate=October 14, 2014 }}{{Cite news|url=https://www.theringer.com/tv/2018/3/19/17131052/bill-hader-barry-show-hbo|title=The Name’s Hader … Bill Hader|work=The Ringer|access-date=2018-04-20}} Mullally, her interest piqued, wanted to see their work personally and, after attending one of the group’s backyard appearances, she informed Hader of her intention to discuss him, specifically, with [[Lorne Michaels]], creator and executive producer of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' (''SNL''). Hader, as a result of Mullally’s recommendation, was asked to audition for the show, and soon flew to New York to audition for a group of ''SNL'' producers. Hader, who would later receive acclaim for his excellent impressions of others while appearing on ''SNL'', had no impressions prepared when he was invited to audition. Despite being nervous and struggling to display his strengths during the audition, this resulted in his spontaneous imitation of an elderly Italian man he had once overheard; this impression would later become the first of Hader’s many recurring characters on the show: Vinny Vedecci. As a result of the audition, Hader got an agent and manager. Just before he was officially invited to begin work on ''SNL'', Hader was working as an assistant editor on ''[[Iron Chef America]]''.{{cite web |url=http://gawker.com/5784918/bill-hader-shares-his-road-to-saturday-night-live |title=Bill Hader Shares His Road to Saturday Night Live |author=Whitney Jefferson |publisher=Gawker Media |work=Gawker |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150115013528/http://gawker.com/5784918/bill-hader-shares-his-road-to-saturday-night-live |archivedate=January 15, 2015 |df=mdy }} ===''Saturday Night Live''=== Hader was hired as a featured player and made his debut on the show on October 1, 2005. His first role was as a [[psychologist]] giving his views about life and death during the emergency landing of [[JetBlue Airways Flight 292]]. He felt he had gone from "preschool to [[Harvard]]." He became the "impressions guy," hoping to fill a utility-player role "like his hero [[Phil Hartman]]". Hader has said that he performed impersonations of teachers and friends when he was growing up but did not do impersonations of famous people until his ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' audition.[http://billhaderonline.com/main/2007/10/08/bill-hader-does-interview-with-bill-hader-online "Bill Hader does interview with BHO!"]. Retrieved October 14, 2007. His list of impressions includes [[Vincent Price]] in the Variety Vault sketches, [[Harvey Fierstein]], [[Charlie Rose]], [[Al Pacino]], [[Brian Grazer]], [[Rick Perry]], [[John Malkovich]], [[Seth Rogen]], [[James Carville]], [[Steven Van Zandt]] (as [[Silvio Dante]]), [[Julian Assange]], [[Eliot Spitzer]], [[Alan Alda]], [[Clint Eastwood]], and [[Charlie Sheen]]. On July 19, 2012, Hader received his first nomination for a [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series]] for his work on ''SNL''.{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/race/emmys-2012-saturday-night-live-bill-hader-351992|title=Emmys 2012: 'SNL's' Bill Hader Shocked By Nomination, Says It Wasn't on His Radar|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=July 19, 2012|first=Philiana|last=Ng|date=July 19, 2012}}{{cite news| url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/07/19/emmy-nominees-bill-hader-of-saturday-night-live/ | work=The New York Times | first=Dave | last=Itzkoff | title=Emmy Nominees: Bill Hader of 'Saturday Night Live' | date=July 19, 2012}} He is the first male ''SNL'' cast member to receive this nomination since Eddie Murphy in 1984. Despite this, Hader suffered from anxiety and sleep problems during his tenure at the program. He never felt "truly comfortable" throughout his first four seasons. He was insecure that he had less comedy experience than his peers. He would often not sleep on Fridays before the show, and would feel light-headed prior to broadcasts. He was neurotic regarding his performances; Hader called his early performances "rigid". On one occasion, he began having a [[panic attack]], live, while impersonating Assange. It was the final episode of 2010, and Hader remembered it: "It felt like someone was sitting on my chest. I couldn’t breathe, I started sweating. I thought, ''This is not good — abort! abort!''" Michaels tried to put him at ease by remarking to him, "You can work here as long as you want," after one show hosted by [[Seth Rogen]]. Hader decided to leave ''SNL'' after eight seasons, informing cast and crew of his decision in February 2013. He came to the conclusion that he needed to leave when his then-wife and he were constantly having to travel to Los Angeles for work, which made it difficult for their children. Working on the program had become difficult upon the birth of his first daughter, and even more so when his second child arrived.{{cite news|title=Interview: Bill Hader|work=[[Interview (magazine)|Interview]]|author=[[Danny McBride]]|url=http://www.interviewmagazine.com/film/bill-hader#_|accessdate=November 26, 2015}} His final episode was on May 18, 2013.{{cite news|title=Bill Hader to Leave ''Saturday Night Live''|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/15/arts/television/bill-hader-to-leave-saturday-night-live.html?partner=rss&emc=rss&smid=tw-nytimes&_r=0|publisher=NY Times|accessdate=May 14, 2013|first=Dave|last=Itzkoff|date=May 14, 2013}} "It was a hard decision, but it has to happen at some point," he told reporters. "It got to a point where I said, 'Maybe it's just time to go.'"{{cite web|url=http://www.jdjournal.com/2013/05/15/bill-hader-leaves-saturday-night-live/|title=Bill Hader Leaves Saturday Night Live – JD Journal|author=Daniel June|date=May 15, 2013|work=jdjournal.com}} On October 11, 2014, Hader returned as host with musical guest [[Hozier (musician)|Hozier]]{{cite web|last1=Perkins|first1=Dennis|title=''Saturday Night Live'': "Bill Hader/Hozier"|url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/saturday-night-live-bill-haderhozier-210385|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|accessdate=August 2, 2016|date=October 12, 2014}} and on March 17, 2018 with musical guest [[Arcade Fire]]. Among the characters Hader played was [[Stefon]], ''[[Weekend Update|Weekend Update's]]'' flamboyant New York City correspondent, whose recommendations consist solely of bizarre nightclubs involving nightmarish characters. Stefon is in love with and married to [[Seth Meyers]].{{cite web|last1=Jue|first1=Teresa|title=Bill Hader discusses the origins of Stefon on 'Seth Meyers'|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2014/09/16/bill-hader-discusses-the-origins-of-stefon-on-late-night-with-seth-meyers|website=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=August 2, 2016|date=September 16, 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Busis|first1=Hillary|title='Saturday Night Live': A full directory of Stefon's favorite clubs. (This post has EVERYTHING.)|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2013/05/17/saturday-night-live-stefon-clubs-everything|website=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=August 2, 2016|date=May 17, 2013}} He was originally a one-shot character on a season-34 sketch where a screenwriter named David Zolesky (played by [[Ben Affleck]]) invites his estranged brother Stefon over to pitch a family-friendly sports drama about a college student who bonds with his grandfather so he can try out for the college football team.{{cite web|last1=Franks|first1=Jonathan|title=Stefon Flashback: In His SNL Debut with Ben Affleck, He Was Just Plain Scary!|url=http://www.inquisitr.com/1536610/stefon-flashback-snl-debut/|website=[[Inquisitr]]|accessdate=August 2, 2016|date=October 12, 2014}} He is based on two people ''SNL'' writer [[John Mulaney]] and Hader met: a wannabe club owner who always invited Mulaney to weird underground clubs and a barista Hader met who looks, speaks, and dresses like Stefon.{{cite web|last1=Dalton|first1=Christine|title=John Mulaney Reveals The Story Behind Stefon On ‘Late Night’|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/04/04/john-mulaney-stefon-late-night_n_5092351.html|website=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=August 2, 2016|date=April 4, 2014}} ===Film roles=== After his film debut ''[[You, Me and Dupree]]'', Hader had a wide range of roles such as [[Katherine Heigl]]'s character's editor at [[E!]] in ''[[Knocked Up]]'',{{cite web|last1=Kirk|first1=Jeremy|title=35 Things We Learned From the ‘Knocked Up’ Commentary|url=https://filmschoolrejects.com/35-things-we-learned-from-the-knocked-up-commentary-f2a65c8e511c|website=Film School Rejects|accessdate=August 3, 2016|date=October 6, 2011}} the acid-taking mechanic Dave in ''[[Hot Rod (film)|Hot Rod]]'' alongside'' SNL'' castmate [[Andy Samberg]],{{cite web|last1=Smith|first1=Edwin|title=A Definitive Ranking of the 11 Funniest Hot Rod Scenes|url=https://www.beamly.com/tv-film/definitive-ranking-11-funniest-hot-rod-scenes|publisher=[[Beamly]]|accessdate=August 3, 2016|date=September 26, 2014}} a recumbent biker in'' [[The Brothers Solomon]]'' (which featured SNL castmate [[Will Forte]] in one of the film's co-leading roles) and, most famously, as Officer Slater in the [[Judd Apatow]] produced'' [[Superbad (film)|Superbad]]''.{{cite web|last1=Yuan|first1=Jada|title=Bill Hader on His Sundance Hit Skeleton Twins, Lip-Synching With Kristen Wiig, and Breaking Into Drama|url=http://www.vulture.com/2014/01/bill-hader-sundance-skeleton-twins-interview.html|website=Vulture|accessdate=August 3, 2016|date=January 30, 2014}} His role in ''Superbad'' helped boost his public awareness and allowed him to appear on mainstream programs like ''Total Request Live'', ''The Tonight Show'', and MTV's ''Video Music Awards''. In 2008, Hader appeared in two other Apatow projects: ''[[Forgetting Sarah Marshall]] '' and ''[[Pineapple Express (film)|Pineapple Express]]''. He also starred alongside [[Ben Stiller]], [[Robert Downey, Jr.]] and [[Tom Cruise]] in ''[[Tropic Thunder]]''. Hader has teamed up with director [[Greg Mottola]] for three feature films: ''[[Superbad (film)|Superbad]]'', ''[[Adventureland (film)|Adventureland]]'' and ''[[Paul (film)|Paul]]''. He made a small appearance in the 2009 film ''[[Year One (film)|Year One]]'' with [[Jack Black]] and [[Michael Cera]]. Hader lent his voice to the critically acclaimed{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1196077-cloudy_with_a_chance_of_meatballs/|title=Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs|date=September 18, 2009|work=rottentomatoes.com}} 2009 [[Sony Pictures Animation]] film ''[[Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs (film)|Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs]]'', as well as its sequel, playing the lead role of Flint Lockwood as well as his invention in the films, the FLDSMDFR. He voiced a gazelle in ''[[Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs]]''. Hader appeared in ''[[Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian]]'' as [[Major General]] [[George Armstrong Custer]]. In April 2009, Hader was a part of ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'''s list of "Comedy's New Legends".[http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/features/2009/04/comedians-portfolio200904?slide=4#globalNav "Laughing Matter: Comedy’s New Legends"] ''Vanity Fair'', April 2009. He provided a voiceover in the 2010 film ''[[Scott Pilgrim vs. the World]]''. He portrayed "The Voice", the disembodied voice that pops up during certain moments of the film's video game-inspired fight scenes. He also had a small cameo as the voice of the USS ''Vengeance'' computer in 2013's ''[[Star Trek Into Darkness]].'' Hader starred in a dramatic role in the 2014 film ''[[The Skeleton Twins]]'', opposite [[Kristen Wiig]], with whom he worked on ''Saturday Night Live''. The film won for 'Best Screenplay' at the [[Sundance Film Festival]]. In 2015, Hader voiced the character of Fear in the critically acclaimed Disney-Pixar film, ''[[Inside Out (2015 film)|Inside Out]]'', and was attached to voice a dinosaur in the Pixar film ''[[The Good Dinosaur]]''. However, Hader, alongside [[John Lithgow]], [[Lucas Neff]], [[Neil Patrick Harris]] and [[Judy Greer]], left the project after their characters were re-designed.{{cite web|last=Thill |first=Scott |url=http://www.cartoonbrew.com/pixar/good-dinosaur-cast-114419.html |title=Pixar Suddenly Reshuffles 'The Good Dinosaur' Cast |publisher=Cartoonbrew.com |date=2015-06-15 |accessdate=2016-12-21}} Most recently, Hader had his first romantic-comedy leading man role opposite Amy Schumer in ''[[Trainwreck (film)|Trainwreck]]'' (2015) and as a former college boyfriend to Greta Gerwig's title character, Maggie's, now stable married best friend in ''[[Maggie's Plan]]'' (2015). Hader voiced [[Alpha 5 (Power Rangers)|Alpha 5]] in the 2017 film version of ''[[Power Rangers (film)|Power Rangers]]''.[http://www.ew.com/article/2016/09/22/bill-hader-power-rangers-alpha-5 "Bill Hader to play robot sidekick Alpha 5 in Power Rangers"] ''Entertainment Weekly'', September 2016. Hader will star in ''[[It – Chapter Two|It: Chapter Two]]'' as the adult Richie Tozier in the upcoming sequel to the first ''[[It (2017 film)|IT]]'' film, alongside [[Jessica Chastain]] and [[James McAvoy]]. The film is set to hit theaters September 2019.{{Cite news|url=https://www.gamesradar.com/it-2-cast/|title=It 2 has revealed its grown up stars, and you're gonna like this roll call|work=facebook.com/gamesradarplus/|access-date=2018-05-22|language=en}} ===Other work=== Hader has made several short films, including ''Back in the Day'', ''Sounds Good to Me: Remastering the Sting'', and ''The Jeannie Tate Show'' with ''SNL'' writer Liz Cackowski and then-wife Maggie Carey. Hader has been a [[creative consultant]] and producer on ''[[South Park]]'' since the show's [[South Park (season 12)|12th season]].Toal, Drew (March 26, 2009). [http://newyork.timeout.com/articles/hot-seat/72706/bill-hader "The Hot Seat: Bill Hader"]. ''[[Time Out New York]]''. His involvement in the series stems from his friendship with [[Matt Stone]]; the two held a similar sense of humor and Hader began going on writers' retreats with the staff. He began working on the program hoping to learn story structure. Hader is among the series producers to win the 2009 Emmy Award for Best Animated Series. He also appeared on the commentary recorded for the 2009 Blu-ray edition of ''[[South Park: Bigger, Longer and Uncut]]'', and the [[Comedy Central]] special ''[[6 Days to Air]]'', a documentary filmed during production of the 2011 ''South Park'' episode "[[HumancentiPad]]." Hader rejoined the writing staff for ''South Park'' for its [[South Park (season 17)|17th season]].{{cite web|url=http://splitsider.com/2013/07/bill-hader-is-writing-for-south-park-full-time-this-season/|title=Bill Hader Is Writing for 'South Park' Full-Time This Season – Splitsider|work=Splitsider}} Hader won a 2008 Peabody Award in Political Satire for his participation in ''Saturday Night Live''. He has also been on the MTV show ''[[Punk'd]]''. Hader voiced an array of different characters on the second season of the [[Adult Swim]] show ''[[Xavier: Renegade Angel]].'' Hader and ''SNL'' castmate [[Seth Meyers]] penned a Spider-Man one-off entitled ''The Short Halloween''. It was illustrated by [[Kevin Maguire (artist)|Kevin Maguire]] and came out May 29, 2009. It was given three and a half out of five stars by Benjamin Birdie of [[Comic Book Resources]].Birdie, Benjamin (May 28, 2009). [http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=user_review&id=1058 "Spider-Man: The Short Halloween #1"]. [[Comic Book Resources]]. Hader took on the voice role of Professor Impossible on the fourth season of ''[[The Venture Brothers]]'', a part originated by [[Stephen Colbert]]. In the game ''[[Grand Theft Auto IV]]'', he played Wilson Taylor, Sr., (on in-game radio show: ''[[Public Liberty Radio|Pacemaker]]''). Hader appeared on ''[[Tim and Eric Awesome Show]]'' impersonating the recurring character James Quall on the episode "Jazz". In July 2008, Hader starred in, and cowrote with [[Simon Rich]], the web series ''The Line'' on [[Crackle (company)|Crackle]].{{cite web | title = Bill Hader Video! "The Line" Episode 1 | publisher = The Deadbolt | url = http://billhaderonline.com/main/2008/07/22/bill-hader-video-the-line-episode-1/ | date= July 22, 2008 | accessdate = 2009-02-27| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090313122853/http://billhaderonline.com/main/2008/07/22/bill-hader-video-the-line-episode-1/| archivedate= March 13, 2009 | deadurl= no}} Hader lent his voice to the [[audiobook]] of [[Sarah Vowell]]'s ''[[The Wordy Shipmates]].'' He voiced the Pod in the ''[[Aqua Teen Hunger Force]]'' episode "IAMAPOD", as well as Hitler in the episode "Der Inflatable Fuhrer". Hader played Kevin, [[Matt Damon]]'s copilot, in the live episode of ''[[30 Rock]],'' recorded October 14, 2010. He hosted the 2011 and 2012 seasons of ''Essentials, Jr.'' on [[Turner Classic Movies]]. In the series premiere of ''[[The Mindy Project]]'', he guest-starred as Mindy's ex-boyfriend. His character returned later in the first season. Hader voiced Dr. Malocchio in the original [[Hulu]] series ''[[The Awesomes]]''. In 2013, Hader replaced [[Robert Downey, Jr.]], as the voice of [[Mr. Peanut]].{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/popcandy/2013/07/02/bill-hader-mr-peanut-planters/2483269/|title=Bill Hader's new role: Mr. Peanut|publisher=}} He has a severe peanut allergy.{{cite web|url=http://www.peanutallergy.com/videos/peanut-allergy/comedian-bill-hader-talks-peanut-allergy-scare-video|title=Comedian Bill Hader Talks Peanut Allergy Scare (Video)|date=January 30, 2015|publisher=}} In 2015, Hader appeared in ''[[Brooklyn Nine-Nine]]'' as the captain of the 99th Precinct.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hDX5gINaZws|title=Brooklyn Nine-Nine Season 3 Promo "New Captain" (HD)|first=|last=tvpromosdb|date=September 6, 2015|publisher=|via=YouTube}} Also in 2015, Hader reunited with fellow ''SNL'' alumnus Fred Armisen for the [[IFC (U.S. TV network)|IFC]] mockumentary series ''[[Documentary Now!]]'', wherein he was an actor and a writer. [[Drew McWeeny]] of [[HitFix]] reported in December 2015 that the voice of [[BB-8]] was supplied by Hader and [[Ben Schwartz]], both credited as "BB-8 vocal consultants" in the film. The voice was created by Abrams manipulating their voices through a [[talkbox]], attached to an [[iPad]] running a sound-effects app.{{cite web |url=http://www.hitfix.com/motion-captured/wait-a-minute-who-played-the-voice-of-bb-8-in-star-wars-the-force-awakens |title=Wait a minute... who played the voice of BB-8 in ''Star Wars: The Force Awakens''? |publisher=[[HitFix]] |first=Drew |last=McWeeny |authorlink=Drew McWeeny |date=December 15, 2015 |accessdate=December 16, 2015}} Hader also voiced multiple characters in [[YouTube]] channel [[Bad Lip Reading]]'s parodies of the [[Original trilogy|''Star Wars'' original trilogy]]. In 2018, Hader created and began starring in the [[HBO]] series ''[[Barry (TV series)|Barry]]'', for which he received four [[Primetime Emmy Award]] nominations as producer, writer, director, and
